item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
You can build raw images as per:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Kicksecure ™ VM Build Documentation

Instructions to build Kicksecure Images from Source Code.

See also:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Image Formats Development Considerations

Considerations for the default file image format in Kicksecure: Is ISO a required image format, or can it be substituted by RAW images?

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @xianhua
item.description: could you summarize the technical challenges for creating an kick .img file?

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
xianhua:

So you prefer using the .img format for persistence and ease of file creation.

Is it possible that a persistent Kick image is available.

Already answered in https://forums.kicksecure.com/t/kicksecure-whonix-liveusb-distromorph/1095/15:

Patrick:

Easier, yes.

Desirable, yes.

Not implemented because, quote Installation of Kicksecure on a USB

Why not just flash a persistent Kicksecure image to USB? - Such an image has not been developed yet due to complex technical challenges. Note that due to these complex challenges, almost no other Linux distributions offer such functionality either. To circumvent this, a “detour” through flashing a Kicksecure ISO is required to run the Kicksecure installer.

xianhua:

Is it possible to distromorph a raspberry pi (raspbian, Pi OS) into kicksecure?

Morphing Raspberry Pi OS into Kicksecure is untested and not recommended, RPiOS is a Debian derivative that departs from Debian in some substantial ways, morphing it into Kicksecure may cause issues.

You may be able to morph Debian 12 into Kicksecure on the Raspberry Pi 4B with decent results if you have sufficient technical skill. The boot process on the RPi is different enough from a traditional PC that it will cause some difficulties (for instance, hardening kernel parameters used by Kicksecure won’t be applied by default), and this isn’t explicitly tested or supported yet. It would be best to try following the existing Kicksecure distribution morphing documentation to start. This is not something we can support yet, so if you run into issues, you may be more-or-less on your own.

Official Raspberry Pi support is planned but not yet present. There isn’t an ETA on it.

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
xianhua:

How should a kick user proceed to create a persistent USB if there is an indication

of a system compromise?

Kicksecure – 29 Nov 24

Compromise Recovery

In the event of a system compromise, users to have a plan in place to contain and recover from the a malware infection while preventing re-infection.

xianhua:

Isn’t that a reason to have an persistent .iso available as a download?

It’s a technical necessity. I am not a huge fan of ISO images.

(Why? → Image Formats Development Considerations)

We don’t refer to it as “persistent ISO”. That’s a contradiction as per our definition.

item.title: Investigate security (SUID) impact of polkitd and policykit libraries
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Documented just now:

Kicksecure – 27 Jun 25

Polkit (formerly PolicyKit)

Polkit is a component for managing system-wide permissions on Linux systems, including security implications and configuration details.

Future Kicksecure development roadmap:

  • Polkit might no longer run by default in user session.
  • We might run polkit only in sysmaint session by default.

item.title: Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
xianhua:

Can you recommend a reasonably priced open source hardware for creating a

persistent Kicksecure/Whonix USB? Would a Pi work?

Anything reasonably priced and user friendly?

Do you personally have a recommended list of devices that you use and

allow for a smooth workflow.

I have no further comment on top what is documented in the wiki page that I liked to.

xianhua:

how can this be an interface to the UEFI/BIOS code? Or is this not correct.

How would the EFI disk partition, if written to RAM, allow for an interface between

the OS and the UEFI/BIOS API. Is there some sort of shell that can be

accessed between the EFI partition and the SPI chips.

This is out of scope for support on this forum.

User documentation, actionable steps what users can do are documented in the wiki as far as we could document it. There is also a lot information about past attacks, potential attacks and tons of links you can follow to learn more.

Discussion on specific attacks on EFI are out of scope. There’s a a plethora of information on the internet. Search terms such as:

  • attacks on EFI

  • breaking firmware

There are many websites and video presentations dealing with this topic.

There is so much information, if you wish to study this, they can keep you busy for years.

item.title: Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?
item.dc:creator: @xianhua
item.description:
how can this be an interface to the UEFI/BIOS code? Or is this not correct.

How would the EFI disk partition, if written to RAM, allow for an interface between

the OS and the UEFI/BIOS API. Is there some sort of shell that can be

accessed between the EFI partition and the SPI chips.

item.title: Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: The EFI system partition is a partition on the disk, it is not a firmware component. It’s usually the first partition on a disk, usually uses the FAT32 filesystem, and usually has a directory named EFI in it.

item.title: Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?
item.dc:creator: @xianhua
item.description: EFI partition is stored on the SPI chips, or is disk partition?

item.title: Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Unspecific to Kicksecure.

Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Potential Solutions Beyond Kicksecure!

Explore resources outside of Kicksecure to address unspecific questions or issues.

Can be resolved as per:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

Definition of the Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

xianhua:

Could UEFI/BIOS exploits/rootkits be a potential source of compromise?

It is. Related wiki pages:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Firmware Security and Updates

Firmware Security and Updating Issues

Kicksecure – 19 May 25

Boot Firmware

This page provides a detailed overview of Kicksecure's compatibility with different boot firmware options such as BIOS, EFI, SecureBoot, and coreboot. It also explains the key differences between BIOS and EFI, and offers guidance on selecting the...

xianhua:

Could this be done using something like IntelME?

Probably. See:

Kicksecure – 22 May 25

Open Source Hardware

Establishing Hardware Trust, Open-source Hardware Alternatives

xianhua:

Is there an API that is capable of briding the firmware(BIOS/UEFI) with an OS,

Search term:
efivars

You can also copy and paste that question into search engines and AI search tools.

Kicksecure – 28 May 25

Utilize Search Engines, Documentation and AI

Avoid basic questions. Effective use of forum search, search engines and AI (Artificial Intelligence). Utilizing extensive Kicksecure documentation.

xianhua:

Is it possible to PXE boot a bootkit/rootkit, or an RTOS remotely?

I don’t see why not.

xianhua:

Would this networking protocol be wired or wireless?

That doesn’t really matter if wired or wireless. Exploits can be chained, called the exploit chain. There will not be an answer such as:

  • “use only wired and you’re safe”; or
  • "use only wireless and you’re save

Wiki page Open Source Hardware has many facinating links such as about hypothetical CPU backdoors.

Could this be done using something like IntelME?

Which network protocol/service would be used in this case?

item.title: AI chatbot for Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
xianhua:

Is it actually possible to include an LLM AI chatbot into the Kicksecure forum?

xianhua:

Can it be trained on all of the forum post text?

Most likely, yes. Not deemed useful productive use of developer time and money at this point.

Many AI (text generator) companies are independently scraping wiki and forum contents including this website. So contents here are already used for training by many AI companies.

How do I know that? Because I wrote lots of contents and I’ll ask AI tools. Then it’s interesting to see what they make of it.

At time of writing, AI cannot solve operating system issues that haven’t been answered elsewhere already. It doesn’t “understand” the issue (there’s no way to input the actual result and expected result in a way that’s not just only text). And there’s no infrastructure in place so the AI can brute force trying solutions until it finds one that is verified to be the expected result.

“AI” is actually a marketing hype word. The more neutral term is “text generator”. This makes it more clear what to expect and what not to expect.

Such as in this case, I am almost certain, a text generator couldn’t have provided any helpful answer for your question as it’s a unique question asked for the first time on the internet, most likely. It however would have generated lots of unhelpful, confusing text.

Text generators is at this point just a search engine on steroids. For things discussed in writing anywhere (internet, books) before, a text generator can remix and maybe provided good inspiration to help. But unique questions (asking something really new, not just using different words) the text generator cannot provide any helpful response.

Maybe a text generator would be useful as a better search engine to reply some repetitive inquiries. But people asking questions that could be answered using search engines or AI are told to read the this wiki page: Utilize Search Engines, Documentation and AI

The strategy is to have a polished wiki with correct information rather than a smooth babbling text generator spewing out unverified information. In the wiki, we care about correctness but a text generator doesn’t understand what truth is and only generates a stream of words based on probability.

Working on any AI integration would require a massive shift in development focus. It cannot be a side project.

Related:

Kicksecure – 9 May 25

Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Artificial Intelligence is an Euphemism. / AI is often called Open Source but is actually only non-freedom software.

xianhua:

Is there a Discourse plugin

for an LLM chatbot?

There’s some stuff:

Whonix Forum – 23 Nov 23

discourse integration - Change Whonix forum software to discourse

Website

Needs research what kind of data is sent to the AI. Typing pattern? Bad. Only public information? Maybe OK. Or maybe only suitable if using local AI only instead of remote (API) based AI.

There is no ETA (estimated time of arrival).

Kicksecure – 28 May 25

Follow Kicksecure Developments

It is absolutely crucial to subscribe to and read the latest Kicksecure news category 'important-news' to stay in touch with ongoing developments. This way users benefit from notifications concerning important security advisories, potential upgrade...

xianhua:

“install-host” simply launches the Calamares installer tool again, this

Detailed instructions added here just now:
Calamares ISO Installer - Logs Access

xianhua:

I can appreciate that there is finite resources to fix these issues, I wonder what

could improve this.

Many answers are possible. I am not sure I can provide any better answer than any AI chat bot.

One answer is money and/or volunteers

That is a highly complex complex question that are probably most projects asking themselves. Also highly speculative, opinionated, with the potential of lots of distracting discussion with no action.

Related:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Open Source Business Models

Overview of Open Source Business Models, their issues, common misconceptions.

item.description:
In my direct experience, that is in fact the source of the bug.

“install-host” simply launches the Calamares installer tool again, this

doesn’t produce any sort of log.

You can access the log using “toggle log” only until the installer is finished

and then it completely disappears. This is just constructive feedback.

Kicksecure is release under which software license? It is a non-profit?

I can appreciate that there is finite resources to fix these issues, I wonder what

could improve this.

Regards nOrphf

item.title: Bug: Calamares installer, uncheck disk encryption can't press next
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
This is unfortunately a known bug, we fixed it in upstream Calamares but were unable to get the fixed version of Calamares into Debian’s bookworm-backports repository (and thus into Kicksecure). You can work around it by editing /etc/calamares/modules/partition.conf and setting preCheckEncryption to false. Then run the installer.

Once Kicksecure is ported to Debian Trixie, this should no longer be an issue.

item.title: Questions regarding use of tmpfs formatting and conflicts
item.dc:creator: @FlapJacket
item.description:
Many messaging applications stores files/avatars in .cache or follow the XDG env specifications. I will put this here but feel free to keep it or move it to another thread or use for wiki. Also if anything is incorrect though I researched this pretty well also feel free to correct it.

  • XMPP

Gajim client handles avatars and cached files shared or opened chats in ~/.cache/gajim/ following XDG Base Directory Specification

Dino (version 0.4.5 or later) client only caches avatars in ~/.cache/dino partially following XDG specifications.

Both Gajim and Dino have automatic previews turned off meaning that files shared in public chats are not automatically downloaded by the client simply by being in a public chat room.
The user has to specifically click on them to or prompt to download them.
Dino will auto download shared files in private chats, Gajim on the other hand does not.

  • IRC

Hexchat saves shared files in local Downloads folder typically.

Hexchat does not have auto downloads for shared images in IRC chats by default. However below is a defense in depth config to download files in RAM following the theme of this thread. Though its better advised to rely on “Live-Mode”:

# Directory for initial file downloads
## Default download location is ~/Downloads
# Save to .tmp if mounted to tmpfs
dcc_dir = ./tmp
## Save to ~/.cache
## Not needed if tmp is mounted to tmpfs or also cache is mounted to tmp and tmp is mounted to tmpfs
#dcc_dir = ~/.cache
## Toggles automatic removal of finished/failed transfers when set to 1
#dcc_remove = 1 
# Disable automatic opening for received files
## Asks for confirmation before downloading (default behavior).
dcc_auto_recv = 0
## Disables auto-opening for incoming file transfers.
#gui_autoopen_recv =0
  • Matrix

Element client follows XDG specifications for caching shared files and avatars in ~/.cache/Element/

Nheko client typically caches shared images and avatars in the ~/.cache/nheko/ adhering to the XDG Base Directory Specification however I’m not sure if that is correct since its been ahile since I used this client.

  • SimpleX Chat

SimpleX Sends link previews by default and auto accept images is enabled by default as of v6.3.5 release.

It also appears they don’t follow XDG specification (atleast for the AppImage version)

Files shared/opened are stored here: ~/.local/share/simplex/simplex_v1_files

To make turn these settings off make sure you go to config ~/.config/simplex/properties check these lines are set:

PrivacyAcceptImages=false
PrivacyLinkPreviews=false

item.title: Questions regarding use of tmpfs formatting and conflicts
item.dc:creator: @FlapJacket
item.description:
Quiksilver:

First let me ask what is your use case for wanting to mount .cache to RAM?

My use case is having certain applications like messaging apps and browsers store cache in RAM even when not in live mode so I things I’m working on still their while maintaining protection when communicating with randoms and online communities in public chats on messaging apps.

Really trying to not have to worry about people spamming weirdo sh*t or malware and my device saving these files just cause I joined a group chat or clicked open preview of something that someone shared in a chat.

Most applications are pretty good now in regards to not having auto previews turned on since its a security risk. Not all applications are made equally though. iMessage on iOS was exploited many times via auto-previews or links previews since it would auto download a image/file or a url link that would exploit a zero day. Not to mention someone could send you something illegal and it would be downloaded to your phone automatically, though this has been patched its still a concern with open source privacy based communications.

Quiksilver:

The other method you mentioned you would prob have to rm and recreate the directory before you syslink it

Thanks thats what I was thinking also. Syslinks might get corrupted or overided by updates too right?

Like when updating applications for example.

item.title: Questions regarding use of tmpfs formatting and conflicts
item.dc:creator: @FlapJacket
item.description:
Patrick:

As distribution developers, it’s hard for us to control the environment in this setup.

Makes sense I understand that. To further clarify what I mean and what I’m trying to understand is if I have XDG_CACHE_HOME=/tmp set and .cache mounted to tmpfs/tmp will there be any gotchas footguns or bottlenecks with Live Mode also?

It appears that grub-live dracut mounts half the system memory for system & home folders /run etc. then the rest of free space is the other half of RAM. If I boot into live mode and look at download directory it says somewhere around 5GB of free space and my total RAM is roughly around 12GB. I don’t think many users might know this about live mode.

This is also the same with Tails given you can’t download anything bigger then the free RAM available, around half is used in there implementation. Otherwise you have to select the persistent directory if you have it enabled to save files bigger since that directory is not in memory.

Patrick:

No need for any /etc/fstab modifications or anything.

But onto the fstab-vm file line L23 that line doesn’t seem correct the line commited out below (L24) does look correct?

I also am no way implying that Kicksecure should mount or syslink .cache to tmpfs/tmp by default configuration.

Patrick:

Did you perform a Functionality Test of Live mode and found unexpected persistence?

Yes, and no I have not found any unexpected persistence with tests.
I will be installing via the ISO here though to look at defaults that are separate from distro morphing.

item.title: Bug: Calamares installer, uncheck disk encryption can't press next
item.dc:creator: @nOrphf
item.description:
Hi

When installing Kicksecure, if you select to erase disk and unselect encryption the two password box but encrypt is still selected.
If you press the tick mark again, the tick mark disappears, but you can’t press next, the button isn’t made clickable.

See more here:
https ://streamable.com/p8jnkd

Doing manual disk partitioning is the only way I have found to get past without disk encryption.

This is happening for both a Hyper-V, VirtualBox and Physical PC installation.
Selected language: English GB
selected timezone: Copenhagen (Locale en-GB, formats DK)
Selected keyboard: Danish (No dead keys)

Regards Lars.

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
xianhua:

Is there a better way to get a log file?

Open a terminal. Run

install-host

The extensive output there includes the installer log.

xianhua:

The log file is extensive, is there any specific error to look for?

No. Calamares isn’t in its entirety isn’t developed by Kicksecure. Nor are most of the tools included. It’s Open Source. Based on thousands of people developing software.

The way it works:

  1. there is an issue
  2. log is provided
  3. developer reads, searches logs

What probably does not exist: Developers memorizing the debug output so well that they can tell you selectively what to copy and what to leave out. Requires too much time to think about and explain.

xianhua:

In general with kick, there appears to be a problem with the installation of

bootloaders onto the USB stick, because when attempting to boot, it doesn’t

recognize an OS.

There might be a bug on some hardware, which we’ll fix in the next release:

Installing Kicksecure to usb stick Support
I keep getting this error when trying to install onto a usb . Thanks. Failed to unpack image "/run/initramfs/live/live/filesystem.squashfs* Details: rsync failed with error code 11!

But that bug isn’t installation of the bootloader to the wrong device.

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @xianhua
item.description:
Couple of issues getting calamares installer logs; when you select “toggle log”

it does show a substantial log of the python installer script, but once the install

is finished, it exits the log screen and it doesn’t allow you to access it again.

Is there a better way to get a log file?

The log file is extensive, is there any specific error to look for?

In general with kick, there appears to be a problem with the installation of

bootloaders onto the USB stick, because when attempting to boot, it doesn’t

recognize an OS.

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
xianhua:

If debug log cannot be obtained then how can I provide the debug log?

A terminal window automatically opens when starting the installer. The massive wall of text is the debug log. Please provide after finishing calamares.

xianhua:

Is there a 3rd party provider which offers Kicksecure support?

Company recommendations are unavailable. A decent software development company with Debian skills should be able.

xianhua:

For the kick xfce .iso file provided there is only a “live” mode.

Because it is a live iso.

xianhua:

In your documentation, it shows a boot menu with “persistent” options.

You can only get that after installing to (internal or external) hard drive.

xianhua:

There is a discrepancy between the docs and the live .iso.

Some screenshot might be outdated saying ISO instead of Live ISO but ISO is always live. We’ll update that at some point in the future.

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph

item.title: Kicksecure/Whonix LiveUSB distromorph

item.description:
My machine well exceeds the minimum RAM requirements. It could

be an error in the Calamares installer that is not detecting the true amount

of RAM available? Possible? Did not notice a separate “Boot loader location”

selection option on my version.

What is the recommended amount of RAM?

xianhua:

Kicksecure?

Unsupported.
